attributes.title: Cognitive dissonance & Pupillometry
attributes.description: An attempt to measure the Cognitive Dissonance State by using pupillometry
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

additionalComments.value: Due to the low number of participants, this study may be underpowered, and thus provide insignificant results.

question2a.value:
For each participant, we show 3 trials of geometrical form-displaying, then by a message summing up what have been displayed, following simple and predictable rules. This method is repeated 4 times first, to habituate the participant. Then, a baseline trial, still with a true message, is displayed. Then, a last trial with false message ends the experiment. Pupil dilation are thus compared in the 5th (baseline) and 6th trial (experimental condition).
The number of displayed geometrical shapes contradictory with the ending message is manipulated (1, 2 or 3).

There are thus 3 conditions : 1 contradictory shape at the last trial, 2 or 3. This variable is between-participant.

question2b.value: Dependent variable is differential pupil dilation between the contradictory message-displaying and the non-contradictory message-displaying.

question3b.value: There are no moderators, but secondary analyses will be proceeded upon contradiction-awareness in the last trial

question10b.value:
1 - Number of contradictions in the experimental trial is randomly determined
2 - Participant is recruited
3 - His/her need for ophthalmological correction is determined
4 - [Using PsychoPy] The procedure is described to the participants. "3 geometrical shapes will be displayed, then a message, summing up these shape, shall be shown. All this may occur several times." 3 examples are given to make sure the participant has understood the rules of the procedure.
5 - [Starting pupillometric recording] The following trial are presented as training. 4 valid trial.
6 - A 5th valid trial is presented, repeating thrice a given shape, then showing the summing up message.
7 - 3 random shapes are shown and then the same message than in trial 5. The number of congruent shapes with the message is determined in step 1.
8 - [Ending pupillometric recording] The trials end. The participant is first asked of he/she has noticed something and, if there is a negative answer, if the message could have been wrong.
9 - The aim of the procedure is explained and the participant is dismissed.

question4b.value: Any adult can be selected, as long as they give their consent and have ability to understand the experiment's rules and attend to it (→ no strong intellectual deficiency, hyperactivity, blindness, etc.).

question5b.value: Data are collected by the mean of a Pupil Lab set up (glasses measuring pupil dilation). The data will be exported on my personal computer and deleted after research's end.

question6b.value:
A such procedure has not been already used, it seems. Thus, a first sample size have been proposed : 120 (total sample). Due to the recording problems with the Pupil Lab glasses, 16 participants have been added for this first step.
After that, an usability coefficient have been calculated for participations : only about 40% of participations provided exploitable data. Moreover, power analysis gave a mean effect size of d=.35, calculated from similar (but not identical) experiments. For the expected analyses, GPower calculated a sample size of 260 participants. To obtain exploitable data, this size, has to be divided by 0,4, giving 744 as a total sample size.
At the same moment, quarantine for nCoviD19 started in France, preventing new manipulations.

The sample size is thus limited to 136 participants.

question8b.value:
Missing data (inability to subtract baseline, e.g.)
Data-based outlier : Leverage index, Cook's D, Student residuals ; QQplot and other similar R analyses ; outlier test on the latter residuals, Jarque-Bera and Durbin-Watson tests.

question7c.value: NA data will be removed for each relevant test. Outlier will be similarly removed, as indicated before.

question1a.value:
Hypothesis 1: Greater pupil dilation when there is a contradictory message, compared to a non-contradictory one.
Hypothesis 2a: Pupil dilation linearly increases with number of previously displayed elements contradictory with the message (cognitive-centred dissonance)
Hypothesis 2b: Pupil dilation linearly increases with number of messages slots contradictory with the expected ones (sensory-centred dissonance)

Exploratory analyses are also intended:
- Examine the chronological evolution of the observed dilation 
- Measure the effect of contradiction awareness on pupil dilation

question3a.value: The contradiction awareness is not a manipulation check, as dissonance can happen without consciousness, causing pupil dilation (Sleegers et al., 2015). There is no manipulation check here, thus.

question6a.value: Hypothesis 2a is the mainstream hypothesis, based on Festinger's theory: the more contradictory elements, the greater dissonance. Hypothesis 2b is an alternative hypothesis with no firm theoretical base, but rather focused on the prediction-making process of participants.

question1c.value:
The differential dilation is calculated as following : dilation when the inconsistent message is presented (trial 6) minus dilation for the same message, but when it's consistent (trial 5).
We expect (hypothesis 1) to get a differential dilation strictly higher than 0

question2c.value: A t test is used to compare the difference of this differential dilation to 0.

question3c.value: The differential dilation being the difference measured (DV) between the two trials (IV), there is no IV. No moderator, covariate, mediator neither: this is a simple relationship.

question1c.value:
The aim it to show if the positive linear relationship between number of inconsistencies in the message and differential dilation is observed.
The way of calculating the differential dilation have been already described. The number of inconsistencies in the messages is calculated by the algorithm, based on the automatic procedure description provided by PsychoPy.

question2c.value:
2 orthogonal contrasts are made :
C1 = -1 0 1 (wanted to be significant and positive)
C2 = 1 -2 1 (intended to be non-significant, otherwise the relationship is quadratic)
A linear model is used to run this test.

question3c.value:
DV: differential dilation
IV: number of inconsistencies in the message

question4c.value: Alternative sensory hypothesis to the previous analysis.

question1c.value: Differential dilation is now calculated for each period of 100 ms, from the beginning of the presentation of the message, until the end of the experimentation. Differential dilation, until then, was calculated on the raw mean.

question2c.value: A simple omnibus F test is used to assess significance of mean dilations differences, for each period of 100ms.

question3c.value:
IV : studied period of 100ms, number of inconsistent stimuli previously presented
DV : differential dilation

question4c.value: This test is used to better understand the dynamics of pupil dilation.

question1c.value:
The aim it to show if the positive linear relationship between number of inconsistent shapes and differential dilation is observed.
The way of calculating the differential dilation have been already described. The number of inconsistent messages is calculated by the algorithm, based on the automatic procedure description provided by PsychoPy.

question2c.value:
2 orthogonal contrasts are made :
C1 = -1 0 1 (wanted to be significant and positive)
C2 = 1 -2 1 (intended to be non-significant, otherwise the relationship is quadratic)
A linear model is used to run this test.

question3c.value:
DV: differential dilation
IV: number of shapes inconsistent with the message

question4c.value: Festinger's (1957) theory predicts that the more inconsistent elements, the greater the dissonance.

question1c.value:
Awareness of inconsistency was measure after the presentation of the wrong message.

Progressive criteria where used, not to induce false positives:
1 - Does the person spontaneously mention it?
2 - Does the person mention it after the question "Have you noticed something particular in this experiment"?
3 - Does the person mention it after the question "Could the ending message be wrong at any time?"

Unawareness was confirmed after three negative criteria.

question3c.value:
IV: Awareness of inconsistency
DV: pupil dilation

question4c.value: Sleegers et al. (2015) showed that dilation didn't depend on awareness, but my opinion is that this experiment is too complicated to elicit an unconscious dissonance. This test would allow to validate one of this two hypotheses.

attributes.title: Up for Grabs? Preferences for Eurozone membership in Italy

q1.value: Up for Grabs? Preferences for Eurozone membership in Italy

q2.value: Lucio Baccaro | Björn Bremer | Erik Neimanns

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: The purpose of this study is to understand which social coalitions support Italy’s support “Italexit” and to what extent support for such a policy is malleable by framing.

q16.value: 1. Hypotheses for support for Italexit: a) Mentioning foreign responsibility increases favorability for Italexit vote b) Mentioning domestic responsibility decreases favorability for Italexit vote c) Mentioning austerity consequences increases favorability for Italexit vote 2. Hypotheses for partisan support: a. Mentioning foreign responsibility increases support for “sovereignist” parties (Lega, FDI, possibly M5S) and decreases support for pro-European parties (PD, Forza Italia, possibly Italia Viva) b. 2b) Mentioning domestic responsibility decreases support for “sovereignist” parties (Lega, FDI, possibly M5S) and increases support for pro-European parties (PD, Forza Italia, possibly Italia Viva) c. Mentioning austerity consequences increases support for “sovereignist” parties (Lega, FDI, possibly M5S) and decreases support for pro-European parties (PD, Forza Italia, possibly Italia Viva) 3. Hypotheses for heterogeneous effects: Framing effects vary by (a) factors relating to economic and political knowledge and information; (b) factors relating to material self-interest; (c) and party and political preferences

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested with a framing experiment, embedded in an original survey that will be fielded among a representative sample of Italian voters (n = 4,200) by SWG, a leading polling company in Italy.

q27.value: SWG, Via San Francesco, 24, Trieste, Italy

attributes.title: Mental Health Outcomes in the ABCD Dataset
attributes.description: Examination of the association between previously identified environmental risk factors for psychotic spectrum disorders and psychotic-like experiences in a large national cohort of adolescents.
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

question2a.value:
All variables are between-participant and orthogonal. Predictor variables include:

Paternal Age at Birth 
Obstetric Complications (Y/N): Heavy Bleeding, Pre/Eclampsia, Gestational Diabetes, Premature Birth, Did Not Breathe, RH incompatible, Birth Weight < 2000, Birth Weight < 2500
Winter/Spring Birth (Y/N)
Household Income 
Average levels of PM 2.5 in 2016
Substance Use Ever (Y/N)
Body Mass Index
Loss of Consciousness (Y/N)
Childhood Trauma (Y/N): Physical, Threatened, and/or Sexual Abuse
Family Conflict (Family Environment Scale - Family Conflict)
Bullied (Y/N)
Migration Status (1st Gen/2nd Gen/Native Born)
Urbanicity (i.e., Population Density)
Area Deprivation Index

question2b.value:
Sum Scores from the Prodromal Questionnaire Brief - Child Version:
Number of Psychotic Like Experiences (PLEs)
Number of Bothersome PLEs
Sum Severity of Bothersome PLEs 
Mean Severity of Bothersome PLEs

question3b.value: Random effects covariates include site and family. Fixed-effect covariates include age, sex at birth, and familial risk for psychosis.

question10b.value:
For rationale concerning demographic, physical and mental health measures, see: Barch, D. M., Albaugh, M. D., Avenevoli, S., Chang, L., Clark, D. B., Glantz, M. D., ... & Alia-Klein, N. (2018). Demographic, physical and mental health assessments in the adolescent brain and cognitive development study: rationale and description. Developmental cognitive neuroscience, 32, 55-66.

For rationale concerning substance use measures, see: Lisdahl, K. M., Sher, K. J., Conway, K. P., Gonzalez, R., Ewing, S. W. F., Nixon, S. J., ... & Heitzeg, M. (2018). Adolescent brain cognitive development (ABCD) study: overview of substance use assessment methods. Developmental cognitive neuroscience, 32, 80-96.

question4b.value:
Not applicable. 2019 NDA baseline ABCD data (release 2.0.1) consisting of 11,869 subjects. 

For sampling rationale see: Garavan, H., Bartsch, H., Conway, K., Decastro, A., Goldstein, R. Z., Heeringa, S., ... & Zahs, D. (2018). Recruiting the ABCD sample: design considerations and procedures. Developmental cognitive neuroscience, 32, 16-22.

question5b.value:
Data was collected from 11,869 9-11 year-olds at the 21 sites of the ABCD study (https://abcdstudy.org/study-sites/).  

For sampling rationale see: Garavan, H., Bartsch, H., Conway, K., Decastro, A., Goldstein, R. Z., Heeringa, S., ... & Zahs, D. (2018). Recruiting the ABCD sample: design considerations and procedures. Developmental cognitive neuroscience, 32, 16-22.

question6b.value:
Data were collected on 11,869 subjects in the 2019 NDA Baseline ABCD data (release 2.0.1).

For sampling rationale see: Garavan, H., Bartsch, H., Conway, K., Decastro, A., Goldstein, R. Z., Heeringa, S., ... & Zahs, D. (2018). Recruiting the ABCD sample: design considerations and procedures. Developmental cognitive neuroscience, 32, 16-22.

question7b.value: Data were already collected on 11,869 subjects in the 2019 NDA Baseline ABCD data (release 2.0.1).

question1a.value: We hypothesize that, after controlling for random effects of site and family nested within site and for fixed effects of age, sex at birth and familial risk for psychosis, adolescent psychotic-like experiences (PLEs) and their associated distress are positively related to the following environmental risk factors: advanced paternal age at the adolescent's birth, obstetric complications before and during the adolescents birth, being born in the winter/spring months, lower parental socioeconomic status, higher levels of pollution, more substance use, a higher body mass index, brain injuries, traumatic experiences, higher levels of family conflict, more adversity, being a migrant, more urban environments, and higher levels of neighborhood deprivation.

question2a.value: We do not expect any interaction effects.

question3a.value: We do not expect to manipulate any variables.

question5a.value:
See following reviews for prediction rationales:

Dean, K., & Murray, R. M. (2005). Environmental risk factors for psychosis. Dialogues in clinical neuroscience, 7(1), 69.

Matheson, S. L., Shepherd, A. M., Laurens, K. R., & Carr, V. J. (2011). A systematic meta-review grading the evidence for non-genetic risk factors and putative antecedents of schizophrenia. Schizophrenia research, 133(1-3), 133-142.

Abrahamyan Empson, L., Baumann, P. S., Söderström, O., Codeluppi, Z., Söderström, D., & Conus, P. (2019). Urbanicity: The need for new avenues to explore the link between urban living and psychosis. Early intervention in psychiatry.

Independent Variables:
Paternal Age at Birth 
Obstetric Complications
Winter/Spring Birth
Household Income 
Average levels of PM 2.5 in 2016
Substance Use in Past 12 months
Body Mass Index
Loss of Consciousness
Childhood Trauma
Family Conflict  
Bullied
Migration Status
Urbanicity 
Area Deprivation Index

Dependent Variables:
Sum Scores from the Prodromal Questionnaire Brief - Child Version (Number of Experiences, Number of Bothersome Experiences,  Sum Severity of Bothersome Experiences, Mean Severity of Bothersome Experiences)

Covariates:
Site 
Family
Age
Sex at Birth
Familial Risk for Psychosis

Variables were obtained through self-report, parent-report, interviews, and US census data.

question2c.value:
Analyses will be conducted using generalized mixed-effects models with subjects nested within family and families nested within site. We will randomly divide the dataset in half, evaluate our hypotheses in the first half, and then cross-validate the findings in the second half. We will also provide model estimates for the entire sample.

For each of the four PLE outcomes,  mixed-effects regressions will be run in a random half of the sample, with composite scores representing the 14 risk factors identified in the hypotheses acting as predictors. We will conduct a regression model including all risk factors, and then subsequently remove a single risk factor. These models will be compared to evaluate which risk factors explain a statistically significant amount of variance in the outcome. For those risk factors that explain variance in the outcome, follow-up analyses will be performed in which the PLE outcome will be regressed on the individual variables that comprise each risk factor construct.

Dependent Variables:
Sum Scores from the Prodromal Questionnaire Brief - Child Version (Number of Experiences, Number of Bothersome Experiences,  Sum Severity of Bothersome Experiences, Mean Severity of Bothersome Experiences)

Covariates:
Site 
Family
Age
Sex at Birth
Familial Risk for Psychosis

question4c.value: We controlled for site and family as random effects and age and sex at birth as fixed effects because these sources of variation are integral to the data sampling scheme of ABCD. We also controlled for familial risk for psychosis, to determine whether the hypothesized independent variables predict PLEs and associated distress above and beyond genetic vulnerability to psychosis.

Migration Status
Urbanicity 
Area Deprivation Index

Dependent Variables:
Sum Scores from the Prodromal Questionnaire Brief - Child Version (Number of Experiences, Number of Bothersome Experiences,  Sum Severity of Bothersome Experiences, Mean Severity of Bothersome Experiences)

Covariates:
Site 
Family
Age
Sex at Birth
Familial Risk for Psychosis

Variables were obtained through self-report, parent-report, interviews, and US census data.

Analyses will be conducted using generalized mixed-effects models with subjects nested within family and families nested within site. We will randomly divide the dataset in half, evaluate our hypotheses in the first half, and then cross-validate the findings in the second half. We will also provide model estimates for the entire sample.

For each of the four PLE outcomes,  mixed-effects regressions will be run in a random half of the sample, with composite scores representing the 14 risk factors identified in the hypotheses acting as predictors. We will conduct a regression model including all risk factors, and then subsequently remove a single risk factor. These models will be compared to evaluate which risk factors explain a statistically significant amount of variance in the outcome. For those risk factors that explain variance in the outcome, follow-up analyses will be performed in which the PLE outcome will be regressed on the individual variables that comprise each risk factor construct.

Independent Variables:
Paternal Age at Birth 
Obstetric Complications
Winter/Spring Birth
Household Income
Average levels of PM 2.5 in 2016
Substance Use in Past 12 months
Body Mass Index
Loss of Consciousness
Childhood Trauma
Family Conflict  
Bullied
Migration Status
Urbanicity 
Area Deprivation Index

Dependent Variables:
Sum Scores from the Prodromal Questionnaire Brief - Child Version (Number of Experiences, Number of Bothersome Experiences,  Sum Severity of Bothersome Experiences, Mean Severity of Bothersome Experiences)

Covariates:
Site 
Family
Age
Sex at Birth
Familial Risk for Psychosis

We controlled for site and family as random effects and age and sex at birth as fixed effects because these sources of variation are integral to the data sampling scheme of ABCD. We also controlled for familial risk for psychosis, to determine whether the hypothesized independent variables predict PLEs and associated distress above and beyond genetic vulnerability to psychosis.

attributes.title: Toward a reliable measure of motor working memory: Revisiting Wu and Coulson’s (2014) movement span task
attributes.description: Some researchers have argued that motor working memory is relatively independent from visuospatial working memory and underlies the learning and processing of motor tasks, like gesture comprehension. To allow systematic testing of these claims, Wu and Coulson (2014) proposed a novel measure of motor working memory, the movement span task. Some studies have reported that the movement span task has a high degree of validity. The purpose of the present study was to attempt to replicate Wu and Coulson (2014) in the following ways: 1) the high correlation between movement span and movement recall scores and 2) the lack of correlation between the movement span task on the one hand and visuospatial and verbal working memory on the other.

attributes.title: Acupuncture plus analgesics for cancer pain: a systematic review and network meta-analysis
attributes.description: Cancer pain is one of most commonly excruciating but often undertreated symptoms among cancer patients. Although a number of randomized clinical trials have shown that acupuncture combined with analgesics may effectively reduce cancer pain. However, results of these studies were not consistent and the comparative efficacy and safety of these methods remains unclear.

q1.value: yin zihan, Mingsheng Sun, Ling Zhao, Fanrong Liang

q2.value:
Cancer pain is one of the most common cancer patients but has not yet been fully resolved, and these papers mentioned “over 70% of cancer patients experience pain, but nearly 50% of these patients are not adequately controlled”. The actual number of people with cancer pain is estimated to be increasing. Moreover, it could lead to chronic pain, mood disturbance, dyspepsia and declined quality of life. These symptoms accompanied by the course of the disease and could make the condition worse. Therefore, cancer pain is a crucial target symptom for the patients and a critical challenge to the world. 
The World Health Organization (WHO) has paid more attention to control it, however, this health problem has not been solved well. Nowadays, it can usually be managed through the skillful application of pharmacologic and non-pharmacologic interventions. Unfortunately, pharmacologic treatments could not always satisfactorily relieve pain, and some patients don’t tolerate their side-effects (craving for opioid, depression, insomnia, constipation, etc). Meanwhile, it has been restrained by the opioid misuse epidemic. Therefore, management of cancer pain is challenging for patients, health departments of governments and doctors will seek a integrative way for cancer pain.
Acupuncture, an ancient Chinese complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) therapy, plays an important role in the treatment of cancer pain . In recent years, acupuncture as a complementary therapy has a positive effect on the treatment of cancer, which is mainly manifested in its obvious advantages in improving patients’ symptoms (pain, mood changes, insomnia, constipation, dyspepsia, dyspnoea, and coughing) . However, many these methods were included in reviews or random controlled trials (RCTs), such as manual acupuncture (MA), electroacupuncture (EA), wrist-ankle acupuncture (WAA), transcutaneous electrical acupoint stimulation (TEAS), fire acupuncture (FA), moxibustion (Mox).
Based on these grounds, many previous systematic reviews/meta-analyses have shown the clinical efficacy and safety of acupuncture for cancer pain, and confirmed that acupuncture is effective in treating cancer pain and improving quality of life. However, these previous studies just have illustrated the single acupuncture therapy against their control treatment for cancer pain. In addition, these SRs only considered the effects of all acupuncture treatments as a whole. We are confused these significant question: Is acupuncture combined with analgesics more effective than using analgesics alone? And based on the current evidence, which acupuncture methods with analgesics would work better? Our research focuses on summarizing the evidence and providing comprehensive, objective and evidence-based information to solve these questions.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Type of Study. 
All RCTs which published in English/Chinese region will be included without any regional restrictions. Non-RCT, quasi-RCTs, cluster RCTs, animal studies, literature reviews, case reports, retrospective studies, and studies which no data are available will not be involved.
Types of Participants. 
All patients with either sex/age who diagnosed with cancer. Participants with all types of cancer pain (pain directly caused by cancer, like visceral cancer pain, bone cancer pain, neuropathic cancer pain) regardless of etiology, ethnic group, severity, diagnosed with specific criteria are eligible for inclusion. Trials that studied cancer pain mixed with other types of pain will be excluded.
Types of interventions. 
We defined intervention as a combinations of any of these acupuncture methods with analgesics, regardless of needling methods and stimulation techniques. Acupuncture methods to be involved were MA, WAA, EA, TEAS, FA and Mox. 
Types of control group.
The control group include individuals who underwent treatment with single analgesics, waiting list group, placebo group.
Types of Outcome Measures 
Primary Outcomes 
A primary outcome of this SR is  reduction of pain intensity. And we measured reduction of pain intensity with Numerical Rating Scale (NRS), Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), Brief Pain Inventory (BPI).
Secondary Outcomes. 
Secondary outcomes included: (1) Consumption of analgesics; (2) Quality of life measured by European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire (EORTC-QLQC30) and KPS (Karnofsky Performance Status); (3) Adverse events. Description of adverse events directly connected with intervention as covered to assess safety measures.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
Two reviewers will be trained in a professional course on NMA. And we will use the intra-group correlation coefficient (ICC) to assess the consistency of reviewers. When selecting a research report, we must first read the title/abstract of the studies to find duplicate research reports and eligible studies. The search results will be uploaded to the database created by NoteExpress V.3.0. 2 reviewers will select through screening the titles, abstracts, and keywords independently. Any differences in research will be resolved through discussions between the two reviewers. If the discussion fails to reach an agreement, the 3rd party will make the final decision.
Data extraction will be performed independently by 2 researchers through standardized qualification forms. If there is a disagreement, an appeal shall be filed with the arbitrator, and the final decision shall be made by the arbitrator. Two researchers will fill the message into Excel. General data for selected studies will be extracted, including first author, year of publication, study design, country, diagnostic criteria, sample size, intervention group, control group, duration of disease, outcome, follow-up time, etc. When the data of articles are sufficient or ambiguous, one of the reviewers will contact the original author to require information by telephone or e-mail. If it is not available, it will be described in the report. The selection procedure will be shown in a PRISMA flow chart

RevMan (Review Manager) Version 5.3 software (Cochrane, London, UK) will be used to analyze the data. For each included study, we will use pre-post differences or end-point scores as outcome indicators. 3-arm studies will be separated into two arms for all possible combinations in the meta-analysis. The fixed-effects model will use the Mantel-Haenszel procedure (M-H), otherwise, the random-effects model will be adopted by Der Simonian-Laired procedure (DS-L) will be used. The X2 test and I2 statistic will be used to identify and measure the heterogeneity among the studies. All data will be analyzed with 95% confidence interval (CI). Risk ratio (RR) will be calculated for dichotomous data. While for continuous data, the standard mean differences (SMD) will be used. According to guidelines from the Cochrane Handbook, we consider that there was no heterogeneity when P>.05, I2<50% and the subgroup will be adopted on the condition of significant heterogeneity (P<.05 and/or I2>50%). When the number of included RCTs is more than 10, funnel plots is used to assess reporting bias. 
In the network meta-analysis, STATA software will be used to produce plots of the network meta-analysis for the comparison of each outcome. In the figure, the thickness of the line is positively correlated with the two intervention methods and the size of the points is also proportional to the weight of the sample size of the intervention. Bayesian analysis will be performed using ADDIS with Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method, and it estimates the posterior probability. The software uses 4 chains for simulation. The simulation iterations is set to 50,000. First perform 20,000 adjustment iterations to eliminate the effect of the initial value. Indirect and direct evidence which from all RCTs are integrated according to the node splitting method. Besides, the Gelman-Rubin statistic will be used to evaluate the convergence of the simulation. The potential scale reduced factor (PSRF) reflects the convergence of the model. A PSRF equals to 100% when a treatment is certain to be the best and 0% of a PSRF indicates a treatment to be the worst. Finally, the figure of ranking probability of all interventions is generated, and local inconsistency are evaluated using the node-splitting method.

attributes.title: Speed of Affect and Moral Judgments
attributes.description:
In previous research (Cusimano et al., 2017), we found in three studies that, in a speeded judgment paradigm, self-reported feelings or specific emotions (angry, upset) are slower than moral judgments (badness, blame).  One potential criticism is that the original probes for these report/judgments differed in introspective difficulty. To examine this alternative explanation we designed a new study in which the probes all try to invite a "look inside."  


Cusimano, C., Thapa, S., & Malle, B. F. (2017). Judgment before emotion: People access moral evaluations faster than affective states. In G. Gunzelmann, A. Howes, T. Tenbrink, & E. J. Davelaar (Eds.), Proceedings of the 39th Annual Conference of the Cognitive Science Society (pp. 1848–1853). Cognitive Science Society.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Speed of Affect: Corbani Honors Thesis

other.value: We plan to perform exploratory analyses that test the relationship between RT and rating intensity (on the 1-6 scale). One would standardly expect an inverted U-shape relationship in  that people are faster at the low and high ends of any intensity scale (extremity --> confidence --> judgment speed).  Though this analysis is mostly for internal validity of the data we are curious whether those curves are distinct for different probes.

sample.value:
We will recruit 240 people through Amazon’s Mechanical Turk for a target of 200 valid participants. Due to software limitations, the final number may vary slightly from this target.  We will oversample because we might have up to 20% exclusions. Our recent studies had a lot more "bad subjects" (or bots) than in the past, and we may also have to exclude additional people who are outliers in their reaction times.  If we have to exclude more than 40 participants according to the exclusion criteria above, we will recruit additional participants so that we have recruited at least 200 valid participants. 

The target of 200 is based on the following reasoning. In the original studies we had 100-200 participants in each study, and the effect sizes of affect probes vs. moral probes averaged between d = 0.18 and d = 0.20. The p values were all < .001, so we had ample power with this range of samples. This is largely because the inclusion of random effects terms (for subjects and items) reduces error variance.  From a conservative perspective (and in line with the simpler analysis approach explained above), we can assume a standard paired t test between relevant probe conditions, for which an effect size of 0.18 would require 190 people to get to power .80 at .05.

analyses.value:
1. Traditional within-subject analysis with item-averaging: 
We first identify each person's 3 items assigned to each probe and compute the average response time across the three.  Then we analyze these average RTs for the negative behaviors and their corresponding probes in a one-way w/s ANOVA, with Probe as a four-level factor: BAD, BLAME, ANGRY, UPSET.  We define the primary a priori contrast of Average(BAD, BLAME) vs. Average(ANGRY, UPSET) as the test of the moral vs. affective speed hypothesis.  We also document possible differences between BAD and BLAME and between ANGRY and UPSET.  
    We then repeat the same analyses for the positive behaviors and their corresponding probes. Once more we conduct a one-way w/s ANOVA, with Probe as a four-level factor: Happy, Surprised, Praise, and Good.  We first test an a priori contrast of Average(Praise, Good) vs. Average(Happy, Surprised) as the test of possible nonaffective vs. affective speed differences.  We also explore differences between Happy and Surprised and between Praise and Good.     

2. Linear mixed-effects models: For the negative behaviors and corresponding probes  we regress the reaction times to each item on the four-level Probe factor, with the same contrasts as specified above, but including random intercepts and slopes for each participant as well as a random intercept for each item.  
    We then conduct corresponding analyses for the positive behaviors. 

Because reaction times have distributional challenges we will adopt outlier removals (see below) and, if necessary, apply transformations to deal with the familiar right-skewed tail of RTs. We don't expect any of these operations to change the results.

outliers.value:
Following Malle & Holbrook (2012) we designate RTs < 400 ms as invalid and remove such item responses.  What counts as outliers at the high end is far more difficult to determine.  From the Cusimano et al. (2017) studies we know that most people respond to the probes in under 4 seconds.  To test for robustness we will compare (a) analyses that exclude responses with RT > 4000 ms to (b) analyses that exclude only extremes (within-person outliers defined as z > 3.0) to (c) analyses that only exclude extreme RTs > 10s, the criterion that Cusimano et al. (2017) used.  We assume that all these analyses will lead to convergent conclusions, as the number of outlier items is typically quite small.  If the results show discrepancies we will also introduce nonparametric analyses.  

In addition to trial-based exclusions we will exclude participants as follows:
  
- AMT ID duplicates. 
- Ones who have a range of 0 or 1 in their moral judgments.
- Ones for whom we have to discard more than 25% of their trials following the trial-based criteria above.
- Ones who have more than 2 missing items within their moral judgments.
- Ones that fail to give meaningful English-language answers to both bot screening questions (see below); we will accept *one* incorrect answer as long as it is meaningful English and likely the result of an honest error; e.g., grandmother instead of grandfather, Saturday rather than Wednesday).
- Ones that enter something into the text box they are instructed to leave empty.

Participants start the study with a bot screening in which they need to enter, into free-response text boxes, correct verbal answers to two questions ("What is the day of the week that is two days after Monday?" and "What is another name for someone’s dad’s father?") and follow instructions to enter nothing into a third text box.

dependent.value: We measure response times to question probes of moral judgments and affective states regarding short behavior descriptions.  Each response is a numeric judgment (on the keys 1,2,3,4,5,6 of a standard keyboard) in answer to a question probe (e.g.,  "How BAD does this seem to you?").

conditions.value:
The design is fully within subject.  The major conditions lie in stimulus variations (12 positive, 12 negative behavior descriptions) and probe variations (affective probes: Happy, Surprised, Angry, Upset; moral judgment probes: Blame, Bad, Praise, Good).  Each probe is paired with three behaviors, whereby Happy, Surprised, Praise, and Good are paired with positive behaviors and Angry, Upset, Blame, and Bad are paired with negative behaviors.  The assignments of behaviors to probes are balanced in multiple forms, and the order of behaviors/probes is pseudo-randomized.    

The probes are:
How BAD does this seem to you?  
How GOOD does this seem to you?  
How much BLAME does [he/she] seem to deserve?  
How much PRAISE does [he/she] seem to deserve?  
How ANGRY does this make you?
How HAPPY does this make you?
How UPSET does this make you?
How SURPRISED does this make you?
   
Of note is that the positive behaviors and probes serve two functions: First, they ensure that people don't get into a mindset of negative judgments and emotions and begin to response uniformly but rather have to response to the unpredictable occurrence of either good events or bad events and, within each type, to the unpredictable appearance of one of four possible questions.  In addition, we can test whether the hypothesized slowness of negative emotions is unique to moral violations or also holds for positively valenced events (not necessarily moral) and the emotions of happy and surprise.

hypothesis.value:
In previous research (Cusimano et al., 2017), we found in three studies that, in a speeded judgment paradigm, self-reported feelings or emotions (angry, upset) are slower than moral judgments (badness, blame).  One potential criticism is that the original probes for these report/judgments differed in introspective difficulty.  Specifically, the probe FEEL? was defined as "How much did the story make you FEEL something?"  The probe ANGRY? was defined as "How angry were you (about what happened)?"  and UPSET? was defined as "How upset were you (about what happened)?"  Critics suggested that these affective probes demanded a look "inside," which can slow people down. By contrast, the moral judgments assessed something that happened outside in the world: For example, the probe BAD? was defined as "How BAD was the thing that happened?  The probe BLAME? was defined as "How much BLAME does the main character deserve?"  To examine whether the slower affect reports were due to introspection-demanding probes we designed a new study in which the probes all try to invite a "look inside."  We predict that even with such changes in the probe formulations, moral judgments will be faster than affect/emotion reports.


Cusimano, C., Thapa, S., & Malle, B. F. (2017). Judgment before emotion: People access moral evaluations faster than affective states. In G. Gunzelmann, A. Howes, T. Tenbrink, & E. J. Davelaar (Eds.), Proceedings of the 39th Annual Conference of the Cognitive Science Society (pp. 1848–1853). Cognitive Science Society.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: Speed of Affect: Corbani Honors Thesis
registration_responses.other: We plan to perform exploratory analyses that test the relationship between RT and rating intensity (on the 1-6 scale). One would standardly expect an inverted U-shape relationship in  that people are faster at the low and high ends of any intensity scale (extremity --> confidence --> judgment speed).  Though this analysis is mostly for internal validity of the data we are curious whether those curves are distinct for different probes.
registration_responses.sample:
We will recruit 240 people through Amazon’s Mechanical Turk for a target of 200 valid participants. Due to software limitations, the final number may vary slightly from this target.  We will oversample because we might have up to 20% exclusions. Our recent studies had a lot more "bad subjects" (or bots) than in the past, and we may also have to exclude additional people who are outliers in their reaction times.  If we have to exclude more than 40 participants according to the exclusion criteria above, we will recruit additional participants so that we have recruited at least 200 valid participants. 

The target of 200 is based on the following reasoning. In the original studies we had 100-200 participants in each study, and the effect sizes of affect probes vs. moral probes averaged between d = 0.18 and d = 0.20. The p values were all < .001, so we had ample power with this range of samples. This is largely because the inclusion of random effects terms (for subjects and items) reduces error variance.  From a conservative perspective (and in line with the simpler analysis approach explained above), we can assume a standard paired t test between relevant probe conditions, for which an effect size of 0.18 would require 190 people to get to power .80 at .05.
registration_responses.analyses:
1. Traditional within-subject analysis with item-averaging: 
We first identify each person's 3 items assigned to each probe and compute the average response time across the three.  Then we analyze these average RTs for the negative behaviors and their corresponding probes in a one-way w/s ANOVA, with Probe as a four-level factor: BAD, BLAME, ANGRY, UPSET.  We define the primary a priori contrast of Average(BAD, BLAME) vs. Average(ANGRY, UPSET) as the test of the moral vs. affective speed hypothesis.  We also document possible differences between BAD and BLAME and between ANGRY and UPSET.  
    We then repeat the same analyses for the positive behaviors and their corresponding probes. Once more we conduct a one-way w/s ANOVA, with Probe as a four-level factor: Happy, Surprised, Praise, and Good.  We first test an a priori contrast of Average(Praise, Good) vs. Average(Happy, Surprised) as the test of possible nonaffective vs. affective speed differences.  We also explore differences between Happy and Surprised and between Praise and Good.     

2. Linear mixed-effects models: For the negative behaviors and corresponding probes  we regress the reaction times to each item on the four-level Probe factor, with the same contrasts as specified above, but including random intercepts and slopes for each participant as well as a random intercept for each item.  
    We then conduct corresponding analyses for the positive behaviors. 

Because reaction times have distributional challenges we will adopt outlier removals (see below) and, if necessary, apply transformations to deal with the familiar right-skewed tail of RTs. We don't expect any of these operations to change the results.

attributes.title: Profiles of Major Life Events
attributes.description:
Research on major life events (MLEs) has often ascribed life events certain characteristics (e.g., marriage has a positive valence) without thoroughly examining these claims. This led to two problems: First, any variation in how people experience MLEs was disregarded because each event was ascribed one typical profile. It is, for example, often assumed that all marriages are the same instead of considering individual variations in people’s perception of this event. Second, this typical profile was often created by one or few expert raters without examining how it relates to the actual perceptions of people experiencing the MLE. In this study, we will collect ratings of characteristics of MLEs from external (lay-)raters to examine how these external ratings relate to event characteristics as they are perceived by those who actually experienced the MLE.

To do so, we will compare data on perceived characteristics of MLEs from three sources:
- Ratings of individual perceptions of event characteristics of MLEs by persons who have actually recently experienced it (henceforth: in situ ratings)
- Ratings of individual perceptions of event characteristics by persons who have not experienced it (henceforth: individual ex situ ratings)
Instructions approximately “Imagine you would experience the following life event: _______. How would you probably perceive it?” 
- Ratings of typical perceptions of event characteristics by external raters (henceforth: generalized ex situ ratings): 
Instructions approximately “How do you think young adults experiencing the life event __________ typically perceive it?” 


These data will be used to examine the following research questions. 

1. Research questions regarding in situ ratings:
- How are characteristics of MLEs on average perceived in situ?
- How much do individual in situ perceptions of event characteristics vary within an MLE?
- Are there differences in the variability of perceptions of event characteristics between MLEs or between event characteristic dimensions?

2. Research questions regarding generalized and individual ex situ ratings:  
- How are characteristics of MLEs on average perceived ex situ?
- How much do ex situ raters agree in their ratings of characteristics of MLEs?
- Are there differences in the cross-rater agreement between MLEs or between event characteristic dimensions? 

3. Research questions regarding the relation between the different types of ratings:
- Are there differences between the means of in situ ratings, individual ex situ ratings, and generalized ex situ ratings of characteristics of MLEs?
- Are there differences between the variances of in situ ratings, individual ex situ ratings, and generalized ex situ ratings of characteristics of MLEs?

q1.value: Sarah Kritzler, Andrew Rakhshani, Sophia Terwiel, Ina Fassbender, Brent Donnellan, Richard E. Lucas, Maike Luhmann

q2.value: The purpose of this study is to describe how people perceive a selection of MLEs in situ and ex situ. We do not have or test any hypotheses.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Data from several studies will be used for this project:
in situ ratings
- Data from Studies 2 to 4 from Luhmann, Fassbender, Alcock, & Haehner (2020): cross-sectional online studies
- Data from Next – A Pathways to Character Project (Study 5 in Luhmann et al., 2020): originally a longitudinal online study, but we will use it cross-sectionally. The study design was preregistered (link: https://osf.io/kvf5g/)

Individual ex situ ratings
- Personality and Life Events ([authors blinded for peer-review], unpublished data): cross-sectional online study

Generalized ex situ ratings
- External ratings of major life events ([authors blinded for peer-review], unpublished data): cross-sectional online study. The study design was preregistered (link: https://osf.io/kf7e2?view_only=40dd69d46c0c46f98782597db59ab3e1)

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value:
We preregister this study prior to analysis (regarding the analysis plan preregistered here) of the data. 

All data have already been collected. We accessed raw frequencies of the reported MLEs from all studies providing in situ ratings to select the MLEs to be examined in this study. Additionally, we accessed data from one study providing in situ ratings and calculated standard deviations of in-situ MLE perceptions to determine the required sample size for the generalized ex situ ratings. We also accessed the list of events and preliminary frequencies from the study providing individual ex situ ratings. 

We did not analyze the data in any other way.

question.value: Data from several studies will be used for this project. All data were collected in online surveys. See preregistrations of the study designs for detailed information (see Study design section).

q11.value:
We estimate the following sample sizes:

- n = ~1265 for in situ ratings (ranging from ~253 to ~22 depending on the MLE)
- n = ~800 for individual ex situ ratings (~ 100 per MLE)   
- n = ~300 for generalized ex situ ratings (~80 per MLE)

Note that these sample sizes are estimates and that sample sizes vary between MLEs; final sample sizes will only be determined during data cleaning when responses regarding MLEs that are not of interest and participants that indicated careless responding are removed from the raw datasets and missing values are examined.

q12.value: Since data collections are already finished, sample sizes are generally fixed. We selected the 10 MLE to be examined in detail in this study based on their relevance in the literature on MLE and on their frequencies in the studies providing in situ ratings. We followed suggestions by Cumming (2012) to determine the required sample size for generalized ex situ ratings (see preregistration for this data collection for details: https://osf.io/kf7e2?view_only=40dd69d46c0c46f98782597db59ab3e1).

question.value:
We selected the following 10 MLEs for detailed discussion in the manuscript based on their relevance and representation in the literature on MLEs and on their frequencies in the studies providing self-report data:
- New friendship
- Vacation
- New relationship
- Break up with partner
- Marriage
- Birth of one's own child
- New job
- Graduation (Abitur + cease education successfully)
- Death of a family member
- Serious own illness / injury

Partial results regarding other MLEs might be included in supplementary materials.


We will use the following variables for our analyses:
- MLE: for ex situ ratings, the MLE that participants were asked to rate; for in situ ratings, the MLE category that two independent raters have assigned to the open format descriptions of the participant’s MLE
- Event characteristics: All studies used a version of the Event Characteristics Questionnaire (ECQ; Luhmann, et al., 2020) to assess perceived characteristics of MLEs. The ECQ comprises nine characteristics of MLEs: valence, impact, predictability, challenge, emotional significance, change in world views, social status changes, external control, and extraordinariness.
- Potential moderators (when available):
      - Prior event experience: this variable indicates whether participants have ever experienced the MLE themselves
      - Temporal distance to the event: if the MLE has been experienced before, this variable indicates when it was last experienced
- Indicators of careless responding (when available)
      - Instructed response items (e.g., "Please choose answer option 4") 
      - Items on the usefulness of the data presented at the end of the survey (e.g., "In your honest opinion, should we use your data?")

We will compute scale scores for the ECQ dimensions by reverse coding items when applicable and averaging across all items within each dimension. We will use all available items for the calculations of scale scores, that is, short forms will only use the short form items, but longer forms will use all items.

Our analyses are mostly explorative and descriptive. We will examine and graphically display how characteristics of MLEs are perceived in situ and ex situ. 

Planned analyses for each research question:

1. Research questions regarding in situ ratings:
- How are characteristics of MLEs on average perceived in situ?
We will compute and graphically display mean values of in situ ratings of the event characteristics of our selected MLEs.

- How much do individual in situ perceptions of event characteristics vary within an MLE?
We will compute and graphically display standard deviations of in situ ratings of the event characteristics of our selected MLEs.

- Are there differences in the variability of perceptions of event characteristics between MLEs or between event characteristics dimensions?
We will graphically display and descriptively compare standard deviations of in situ ratings of life event characteristics and of MLEs. 


2. Research questions regarding generalized and individual ex situ ratings:  
- How are characteristics of MLEs on average perceived ex situ?
We will compute and graphically display mean values of generalized and individual ex situ ratings of the life event characteristics of our selected MLEs.

- How much do ex situ raters agree in their ratings of characteristics of MLEs?
We will compute and graphically display standard deviations of generalized and individual ex situ ratings of life event characteristics of our selected MLEs.
 
- Are there differences in the cross-rater agreement between MLEs or between event characteristic dimensions? 
We will graphically display and descriptively compare standard deviations of generalized and individual ex situ ratings of life event characteristics and of MLEs. 


3. Research questions regarding the relation between the different types of ratings:
- Are there differences between the means of in situ ratings, individual ex situ ratings, and generalized ex situ ratings of characteristics of MLEs?
- Are there differences between the variances of in situ ratings, individual ex situ ratings, and generalized ex situ ratings of characteristics of MLEs?
We will graphically display and descriptively compare the means and standard deviations of in situ ratings, individual ex situ ratings, and generalized ex situ ratings of characteristics of our selected MLEs.

q20.value: We will exclude participants who meet criteria for careless responding (when available): Any participant who answered one or more of the instructed-response items incorrectly or who indicated that their data are not useful will be excluded from the analyses.

q21.value: Participants with missing values on variables of interest will be excluded from the respective analyses (i.e., pairwise deletion).

      - Instructed response items (e.g., "Please choose answer option 4") 
      - Items on the usefulness of the data presented at the end of the survey (e.g., "In your honest opinion, should we use your data?")
registration_responses.q16.question: We will compute scale scores for the ECQ dimensions by reverse coding items when applicable and averaging across all items within each dimension. We will use all available items for the calculations of scale scores, that is, short forms will only use the short form items, but longer forms will use all items.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Our analyses are mostly explorative and descriptive. We will examine and graphically display how characteristics of MLEs are perceived in situ and ex situ. 

Planned analyses for each research question:

1. Research questions regarding in situ ratings:
- How are characteristics of MLEs on average perceived in situ?
We will compute and graphically display mean values of in situ ratings of the event characteristics of our selected MLEs.

- How much do individual in situ perceptions of event characteristics vary within an MLE?
We will compute and graphically display standard deviations of in situ ratings of the event characteristics of our selected MLEs.

- Are there differences in the variability of perceptions of event characteristics between MLEs or between event characteristics dimensions?
We will graphically display and descriptively compare standard deviations of in situ ratings of life event characteristics and of MLEs. 


2. Research questions regarding generalized and individual ex situ ratings:  
- How are characteristics of MLEs on average perceived ex situ?
We will compute and graphically display mean values of generalized and individual ex situ ratings of the life event characteristics of our selected MLEs.

- How much do ex situ raters agree in their ratings of characteristics of MLEs?
We will compute and graphically display standard deviations of generalized and individual ex situ ratings of life event characteristics of our selected MLEs.
 
- Are there differences in the cross-rater agreement between MLEs or between event characteristic dimensions? 
We will graphically display and descriptively compare standard deviations of generalized and individual ex situ ratings of life event characteristics and of MLEs. 


3. Research questions regarding the relation between the different types of ratings:
- Are there differences between the means of in situ ratings, individual ex situ ratings, and generalized ex situ ratings of characteristics of MLEs?
- Are there differences between the variances of in situ ratings, individual ex situ ratings, and generalized ex situ ratings of characteristics of MLEs?
We will graphically display and descriptively compare the means and standard deviations of in situ ratings, individual ex situ ratings, and generalized ex situ ratings of characteristics of our selected MLEs.
